HOMEWOOD, BALTIMORE, MD., DECEMBER 8, 1925.

TAU BETA PI
TO INITIATE

For the second consecutive
week an honorary fraternity
will hold its public initiation at the Thursday Assembly, when Tau Beta Pi, honorary engineering society,
will conduct its fall initiation.
Professor Albert Christie
will announce the names of
the initiates, and Mr. Abel
Wolman, a graduate member
of the society, will deliver
the principal address. Mr.
Wolman, who is Chief Engineer of the Maryland State
Department of Public Health,
will speak on some phase of
public health work.

HOMEWOOD, BALTIMORE, MD., DECEMBER 8, 1925.

MIDDLE WESTERN MORALS
The New Student, that constant source of NEWS-LETTER
editorials, recently published the following items:
"Guardians of the plastic age are finding their task, as
usual, a difficult one. From several quarters come pronouncements on the evils of Gin, Jazz, and Co-Education.
"Said Dr. Clarence Cook Little, the new president of the
University of Michigan, in his inauguration speech:
"'In the day of the highly explosive mixture of youth,
gasoline, and liquor borne swiftly on balloon tires to remote
retreats; in an era of college publications skating on the thinnest possible ice of decency, it would take Hercules himself to
guarantee a fair substitute, and I believe that the Augean stables were, in comparison, an early season practice.'
"One of the many conclusions reached at the Y. M. C. A.
State Student Conference at Des Moines, Iowa:
"The evils of petting and the double standard were shown.
Dancing was discussed and the conclusion was reached that
modern dancing is more detrimental than petting.'"
We reproduce these items for the lovers of •the rich and
juicy in literature. We .refrain from calling the attention of
the reader to the elegant diction, the remarkable choice of
words, of the learned Little, of Michigan. We wish to call the
,attention of the campus at large to one fact only,—kindly notice
the section of the country which countenanced the moralistic
opinions of such intelligentsia. We wish to call attention to
the virtues of the Maryland Free State. Here you find few
such opinions; here one can do as he pleases without having
to have the consent of the world at large.
Having finished, we sit back with a sigh; and wait for the
protests of loyal sons of the Middle West to roll in.

December Review of Reviews. It is called "College Football
Today."
In the column and a half which the NEWS-LETTER so sensibly devoted to this news, it was declared that the article "should
have a great effect on public opinion." We do not know
whether we agree with the letter of this statement, since we
do not know just what it means: Hopkins journalese has a collegiate ambiguity to a remarkable degree. To our mind, however, it is true that "College Football Today" should have that
great effect. But we are just cynical enough to believe that
it won't.
As the too timely NEWS-LETTER has already said, "the arguments in it are forceful, the facts undeniable, . . . ." It is,
indeed, an interesting and convincing answer to the usual
objections to the sport. In other words, it is a sort of outline
defense of football, written in simple and clear language. The
fact that it fails to discuss the most important question of
all,—the relation of football to the essential nature of our
educational institutions,—is doubtless due to lack of space.
The excellence of the article lies in its presentation of the facts
significant to the game itself.
The local write-up, however, failed to mention the thing
that intrigued us most. It was the extremely deft juggling
of tenses in one of the paragraphs. Whoever taught Roger
Shaw English Composition should find it a source of considerable pride.
We print it here for the delectation, not to say enlightenment of the English Department:
"Harvard has reached the lowest ebb in the history of
her football career this year. Yet her students continue to
cheer their team with undiminished vigor and enthusiasm,
and her alumni will have flocked from far and near to see

the annual classic

with Yale at Cambridge. These alumni
did not expect to witness a Harvard victory,—it would be
a miracle. But they did expect to cheer the name of their
university and all that name stands for, and wholeheartedly
to support a plucky team. They know that Harvard will
still be Harvard, even amidst a series of crushing defeats.
Their loyal spirit and high ideals of sportsmanship remain
unchanged."
The italics are ours, of course.
Being at present under the strain of replacing a comparatively expensive book which we lost recently, we are reminded
of the wrath of a friend whose copy of "Beyond Good and
Evil" disappeared last Spring from its parking place on the
campus. He is now in full accord with the Geology Department on the subject of taking Nietzsche literally.

At least one member of the Faculty is of the opinion that
the recent Faculty Number of the Black and Blue Jay is reasonably mild and polite.
Why is this?
Is our Faculty too good to be criticized? Is it too pale to
be caricatured? too "white" to be railed at? too perfect to be
satirized? Or is there danger in discussing it frankly?
These are not rhetorical questions. We really want to
know. Of course, we have a few- faint notions of our own.
Any interesting contributions on this subject will be printed

One more link in the chain of
evidence being forged by scientists of today in support of the
theory of evolution was revealed
last Thursday afternoon in a lecture by Dr. Frederick Orpen
Bower, Regius Profesqor of Botany at the University of Glasgow.
He talked on the "Evidence of the
Inheritance of Acquired Characters in the Evolution of Plants."
Dr. Bower is a botanist of distinction. As an author, his scientific works have brought him a
wide reputation.

Specializes

On Fern

In the large range of his learning, he still took time to concentrate upon one species in the plant
world. Out of the thousands of
plants that he has come across
in his chosen field of work, Dr.
Bower selected the fern to study
in minute detail and, incidentally, to lecture upon.
The greater part of his work
centered around the gradual
change through the ages in the
position of the sporangia of the
fern. Sporangia are tiny seed-.
cases which grow in great numbers on the leaves of mature
plants and, eventually, when ripe,
break open their little boxes and
liberate the seeds in order to propagate the species.
Dr. Bower found, in the study
of priinitive types of fern existing now only as fossils, that these
seed-boxes were at first attached
in an unprotected position to the
end or on the side of the leaves.
This position experience showed
to be dangerous to the life of the
sporangia. There was danger
from too great exposure to direct
sunlight. There was the threat of
death by evaporation.
The plant met the emergency.
Gradually, in the steady progress
of centuries, a change took place.
Down in the vital cells of the fern
there was a shifting, a slow alteration, almost imperceptible, but
very real. The plant was adapting a part of itself to its environment; it was changing through
the pressure of adverse conditions.
The sporangia, in the course of
trolls, was shifted from its former unsafe place to a sheltered
position under the leaves. There
they are found today', with very
rare exceptions, on all ferns, protected effectively from sunlight
and evaporation.

CONGRATULATIONS
We take great pleasure in congratulating the new members
of Omicron Delta Kappa upon their election to that body.
The mere fact that 0. D. K..has, for a number of years, been
voted the highest honor that an undergraduate can obtain at
Hopkins is sufficient evidence of the achievement of the men
who were honored last Thursday.
The high standards which the society has upheld in the
past years will, from all indications, be maintained throughout the remainder of the present scholastic year. However,
the job of keeping up to the level of the local circle is one
fraught with much danger, much hardship. There is danger
if the members relax in their work; there is hardship in
extending sufficient effort to keep high the honor of the society.
We believe that the present members are fully capable of the
task.
Again, allow the NEWS-LETTER to extend its hearty congratulations to the new members a Omicroa Delta Kappa.

ALFRED NOYES IS GUEST OF
HONOR AT TUDOR-STUART TEA
Alfred Noyes, the distinguished
English poet, was the guest of
honor at a luncheon given by the
Tudor and Stuart Club last Friday at 12:30 in the rooms of the
Club.
Mr. Noyes was accompanied by
his host, Captain Miles, Headmaster of Gilman Country School.
About thirty-five faculty and student members of the club attended
the luncheon.
After the luncheon Mr. Noyes
recited three of his poems. The
first two of these were Forty Singing Seamen and Mountain Laurel. These were so thorough-

ly enjoyed that he was requested
to give another recitation. He
complied with this by reciting his
most famous lyric poem, The
Highwayman.
Mr. Noyes, who is making a tour
of this country lecturing in prominent cities was brought to Baltimore under the auspices of the
Poetry Society of Maryland. On
Friday evening at 8:30 he gave a
most delightful lecture at one of
the halls of Goucher College.
On Saturday Mr. Noyes left for
Washington where he is to lecture. From there he is to go to
Philadelphia.

These are the facts which Dr.
Bower, after several decades of
close study with the microscope,
has clothed in technical language
and set before the scientific world
in an exhaustive treatise printed
recently in England. His lecture
deals , wtih the essential. details
and conclusions drawn from this
study.
Dr. Bower wished it understood
that he did not derive any general
concepts about evolution from the
single example that he had worked
out. His contribution was a new
set of facts added to the evergrowing collection which ultimately may decide the question
once and for all.
The case of evolution'is still on
trial.

Japanese Alumni
Contribute To Fund
Johns Hopkins alumni in Japan
have pledged 4700 yen lo the HalfCentury Fund. This money,from
thirteen members of the Alumni
Association, has a purchasing
power in Japan equal to about
$4700 in America, and it is expected that a greater amount will be
subscribed in the near future.

HOMEWOOD, BALTIMORE, MD., DECEMBER 8, 1925.

TAU BETA PI
TO INITIATE

For the second consecutive
week an honorary fraternity
will hold its public initiation at the Thursday Assembly, when Tau Beta Pi, honorary engineering society,
will conduct its fall initiation.
Professor Albert Christie
will announce the names of
the initiates, and Mr. Abel
Wolman, a graduate member
of the society, will deliver
the principal address. Mr.
Wolman, who is Chief Engineer of the Maryland State
Department of Public Health,
will speak on some phase of
public health work.

HOMEWOOD, BALTIMORE, MD., DECEMBER 8, 1925.

MIDDLE WESTERN MORALS
The New Student, that constant source of NEWS-LETTER
editorials, recently published the following items:
"Guardians of the plastic age are finding their task, as
usual, a difficult one. From several quarters come pronouncements on the evils of Gin, Jazz, and Co-Education.
"Said Dr. Clarence Cook Little, the new president of the
University of Michigan, in his inauguration speech:
"'In the day of the highly explosive mixture of youth,
gasoline, and liquor borne swiftly on balloon tires to remote
retreats; in an era of college publications skating on the thinnest possible ice of decency, it would take Hercules himself to
guarantee a fair substitute, and I believe that the Augean stables were, in comparison, an early season practice.'
"One of the many conclusions reached at the Y. M. C. A.
State Student Conference at Des Moines, Iowa:
"The evils of petting and the double standard were shown.
Dancing was discussed and the conclusion was reached that
modern dancing is more detrimental than petting.'"
We reproduce these items for the lovers of •the rich and
juicy in literature. We .refrain from calling the attention of
the reader to the elegant diction, the remarkable choice of
words, of the learned Little, of Michigan. We wish to call the
,attention of the campus at large to one fact only,—kindly notice
the section of the country which countenanced the moralistic
opinions of such intelligentsia. We wish to call attention to
the virtues of the Maryland Free State. Here you find few
such opinions; here one can do as he pleases without having
to have the consent of the world at large.
Having finished, we sit back with a sigh; and wait for the
protests of loyal sons of the Middle West to roll in.

December Review of Reviews. It is called "College Football
Today."
In the column and a half which the NEWS-LETTER so sensibly devoted to this news, it was declared that the article "should
have a great effect on public opinion." We do not know
whether we agree with the letter of this statement, since we
do not know just what it means: Hopkins journalese has a collegiate ambiguity to a remarkable degree. To our mind, however, it is true that "College Football Today" should have that
great effect. But we are just cynical enough to believe that
it won't.
As the too timely NEWS-LETTER has already said, "the arguments in it are forceful, the facts undeniable, . . . ." It is,
indeed, an interesting and convincing answer to the usual
objections to the sport. In other words, it is a sort of outline
defense of football, written in simple and clear language. The
fact that it fails to discuss the most important question of
all,—the relation of football to the essential nature of our
educational institutions,—is doubtless due to lack of space.
The excellence of the article lies in its presentation of the facts
significant to the game itself.
The local write-up, however, failed to mention the thing
that intrigued us most. It was the extremely deft juggling
of tenses in one of the paragraphs. Whoever taught Roger
Shaw English Composition should find it a source of considerable pride.
We print it here for the delectation, not to say enlightenment of the English Department:
"Harvard has reached the lowest ebb in the history of
her football career this year. Yet her students continue to
cheer their team with undiminished vigor and enthusiasm,
and her alumni will have flocked from far and near to see

the annual classic

with Yale at Cambridge. These alumni
did not expect to witness a Harvard victory,—it would be
a miracle. But they did expect to cheer the name of their
university and all that name stands for, and wholeheartedly
to support a plucky team. They know that Harvard will
still be Harvard, even amidst a series of crushing defeats.
Their loyal spirit and high ideals of sportsmanship remain
unchanged."
The italics are ours, of course.
Being at present under the strain of replacing a comparatively expensive book which we lost recently, we are reminded
of the wrath of a friend whose copy of "Beyond Good and
Evil" disappeared last Spring from its parking place on the
campus. He is now in full accord with the Geology Department on the subject of taking Nietzsche literally.

At least one member of the Faculty is of the opinion that
the recent Faculty Number of the Black and Blue Jay is reasonably mild and polite.
Why is this?
Is our Faculty too good to be criticized? Is it too pale to
be caricatured? too "white" to be railed at? too perfect to be
satirized? Or is there danger in discussing it frankly?
These are not rhetorical questions. We really want to
know. Of course, we have a few- faint notions of our own.

One more link in the chain of
evidence being forged by scientists of today in support of the
theory of evolution was revealed
last Thursday afternoon in a lecture by Dr. Frederick Orpen
Bower, Regius Profesqor of Botany at the University of Glasgow.
He talked on the "Evidence of the
Inheritance of Acquired Characters in the Evolution of Plants."
Dr. Bower is a botanist of distinction. As an author, his scientific works have brought him a
wide reputation.

Specializes

On Fern

In the large range of his learning, he still took time to concentrate upon one species in the plant
world. Out of the thousands of
plants that he has come across
in his chosen field of work, Dr.
Bower selected the fern to study
in minute detail and, incidentally, to lecture upon.
The greater part of his work
centered around the gradual
change through the ages in the
position of the sporangia of the
fern. Sporangia are tiny seed-.
cases which grow in great numbers on the leaves of mature
plants and, eventually, when ripe,
break open their little boxes and
liberate the seeds in order to propagate the species.
Dr. Bower found, in the study
of priinitive types of fern existing now only as fossils, that these
seed-boxes were at first attached
in an unprotected position to the
end or on the side of the leaves.
This position experience showed
to be dangerous to the life of the
sporangia. There was danger
from too great exposure to direct
sunlight. There was the threat of
death by evaporation.
The plant met the emergency.
Gradually, in the steady progress
of centuries, a change took place.
Down in the vital cells of the fern
there was a shifting, a slow alteration, almost imperceptible, but
very real. The plant was adapting a part of itself to its environment; it was changing through
the pressure of adverse conditions.
The sporangia, in the course of
trolls, was shifted from its former unsafe place to a sheltered
position under the leaves. There
they are found today', with very
rare exceptions, on all ferns, protected effectively from sunlight
and evaporation.

CONGRATULATIONS
We take great pleasure in congratulating the new members
of Omicron Delta Kappa upon their election to that body.
The mere fact that 0. D. K..has, for a number of years, been
voted the highest honor that an undergraduate can obtain at
Hopkins is sufficient evidence of the achievement of the men
who were honored last Thursday.
The high standards which the society has upheld in the
past years will, from all indications, be maintained throughout the remainder of the present scholastic year. However,
the job of keeping up to the level of the local circle is one
fraught with much danger, much hardship. There is danger
if the members relax in their work; there is hardship in
extending sufficient effort to keep high the honor of the society.
We believe that the present members are fully capable of the
task.
Again, allow the NEWS-LETTER to extend its hearty congratulations to the new members a Omicroa Delta Kappa.

ALFRED NOYES IS GUEST OF
HONOR AT TUDOR-STUART TEA
Alfred Noyes, the distinguished
English poet, was the guest of
honor at a luncheon given by the
Tudor and Stuart Club last Friday at 12:30 in the rooms of the
Club.
Mr. Noyes was accompanied by
his host, Captain Miles, Headmaster of Gilman Country School.
About thirty-five faculty and student members of the club attended
the luncheon.
After the luncheon Mr. Noyes
recited three of his poems. The
first two of these were Forty Singing Seamen and Mountain Laurel. These were so thorough-

ly enjoyed that he was requested
to give another recitation. He
complied with this by reciting his
most famous lyric poem, The
Highwayman.
Mr. Noyes, who is making a tour
of this country lecturing in prominent cities was brought to Baltimore under the auspices of the
Poetry Society of Maryland. On
Friday evening at 8:30 he gave a
most delightful lecture at one of
the halls of Goucher College.
On Saturday Mr. Noyes left for
Washington where he is to lecture. From there he is to go to
Philadelphia.

Bower, after several decades of
close study with the microscope,
has clothed in technical language
and set before the scientific world
in an exhaustive treatise printed
recently in England. His lecture
deals , wtih the essential. details
and conclusions drawn from this
study.
Dr. Bower wished it understood
that he did not derive any general
concepts about evolution from the
single example that he had worked
out. His contribution was a new
set of facts added to the evergrowing collection which ultimately may decide the question
once and for all.
The case of evolution'is still on
trial.
